On Friday—I cannot tell exactly at what time—it was in the evening part—I cannot say exactly whether it was at tea-time; it was about four or fire o'clock—my brother and sister, me and the prisoner, were present.

Q. Did you see Valentine, that came from Germany, when he came to visit you? A. Yes, I remember his coming to see us—it is about three weeks ago since he came from Germany—I saw him—my brother and sister were at home—they were greatly surprised to see him—I live with my brother and his wife—I was not present exactly when he came in, I was out with the child—I came in just after—I was there along with him, and my brother and sister were there—I recollect my sister telling him that there was a lady wanted very much to see him, a friend of his—he did not ask who she was; he seemed to know who she was—I did not hear exactly what he said—I did not take notice.

Q. When did you see him next? A. He slept in the house that night—I saw him next in the morning—he breakfasted in the house—I did not hear him talk at all about the lady at breakfast—he was there all day, and slept there the second night—it was not at the time the ticket was taken—he came from Germany after the ticket was taken away, and after the pri
soner was taken up—three: weeks after—he was not at the house when the ticket was taken—he came there since—a good bit since—three weeks since the ticket was taken—he came from Germany—he has been to Ger
many twice.
COURT. Q. After he came and staid these two nights, did you lose sight of him? A. No, he slept and staid there all along—he has staid there ever since, and lives in the house—he is living there now.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You left him there this morning, did you not? A. Yes.

COURT. Q. Left who there? the man that came from Germany? A. Yes, Mr. Valentine—ray brother and sister, Valentine and I, did not breakfast together before we came out this morning—we dined together yesterday, at my brother's house—he lives along with my brother—Mrs. Cooke dined with him yesterday—I dined at the table, and the day before.

COURT to EDWARD COOKE. Q. Now you have heard what your bro
ther has said, how do you explain it? A. Explain what my brother has said, do you mean?
Q. Yes, about this man Valentine living in your house from the time be came to the present day? A. That is all right—I told you I had seen him this morning, at No. 39, James's place.

Q. Why conceal from the Court the fact, that this man was living in your house, and represent that you had been to visit him every day for the last week?—what did you mean by making such a false and wicked repre
sentation
to the Court? A. I did not say he was not living with me—I had been there every day, I said.

COURT to CHARLOTTE COOKS. Q. What did you mean by representing that you had seen your father but once; that he had called but once, when it now turns out that he is actually living in the house? A. Be
cause he told me not to mention about it; he said, he did not wish the lady to know where he was—he did not tell me not to tell the Court where he lived, but not to tell the prisoner.

Q. But when examined on oath, how came you to presume to tell the Court and Jury that you had not seen Mr. Valentine since the day he railed on you, and that you did not know where he lived, when he is living in your own house—how do you reconcile that? A. I do not know, Sir.
NOT GUILTY .
(The witnesses Edward Cooke and Charlotte Cooke were committed.)

1223.
SARAH READ was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 shirt, value 4s.; and I flannel-shirt, value 2s.; the goods of
John Matthew and another: and
JANE MELON
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, & c.

JAMES FREDERICK SYMONS . I am in the service of John and Benjamin Matthew, pawnbrokers, in Liquorpond-street. In the afternoon of the 5th of April, the prisoner Read came to our shop and pawned an apron—about an hour afterwards a policeman came and produced a linen shirt and a flannel shirt, the property of my employers, which I had seen banging up in the shop close by where Read stood, about a minute before she came in—she came alone—I did not miss them till the policeman pro
duced them.
Read. I found them on Eyre Street-hill, and there is mud on the shirt, where I trod on it. Witness. I do not observe any mud on it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you observe any one watch
ing or waiting outside? A. No.

GEORGE WATERLOO HOLLAND (police-constable Q 23.) I took the pri
soners into custody—in the station they were both sitting together, shuffling about, and during the time I took Read to be searched by a fe
male, one of them, I cannot say which, put this linen shirt on the table—if I have said it was Melon, I cannot stick to it—there was no one there but the prisoners to put it there—the sergeant on duty asked Melon if it was her property—she said no, she knew nothing about it—I was ordered to take Read to the cell to be searched by a female—on coming back I found this flannel-shirt under the seat on which they were sitting, which put it there, I cannot say—when the sergeant asked Melon if the linen shirt was hers, she said it was not, it was Read's—Read said it was hers—the sergeant asked whether it was marked—Melon said it was her sister's husband's shirt, and Read said it was hers—Read said it was not marked—Melon said it was marked G. B.—the searcher is not here—it was the flannel-shirt that Melon said she knew nothing about.

JAMES HAHMAN . I am shopman to Mr. Watt, a pawnbroker, in Ex-mouth-street. In the afternoon of the 5th of April the prisoners came to our shop in company together—Melon offered this linen shirt in pledge, but would not take what I offered on it—I observed a flannel under her arm, rolled up, which I believe was a flannel shirt—I did not look at the linen shirt enough to identify it again.
NOT GUILTY .

1224.
SARAH READ was again indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 flannel-petticoat, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
Robert Watt.

JAMES HARMAN . I am in the employ of Robert Watt. On Monday, the 5th of April, about five o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came with Melon, and offered some irons in pledge—I noticed one of them snatch down a petticoat, but they stood so close together, I could not say which it was—I saw Read with the lower part of her person, raise the petticoat, and put it under her arm—I sent a lad for a policeman, who came, and I then said to the prisoner, "Give up that petticoat"—they both cried out, "What do you mean? what petticoat?"—I said, "The petticoat under your arm"—she immediately dropped it from under her arm, and was taken into custody.

Prisoner. I never saw the petticoat—it was never in my possession—there were other persons in the shop. Witness. There was one other per
son at the other end of the shop—I saw it drop from her person.

GEORGE WATERLOO HOLLAND . I am a policeman. I was fetched, and saw the prisoner drop the petticoat from under her left arm, under her shawl—I saw it distinctly fall from her—I picked it up, and took her into custody.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Weeks.

1225.
THOMAS LEONARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, 2lbs. weight of bacon, value 1s. 1d., the goods of
George Waistell.

GEORGE WAISTELL . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Asylum-terrace, Chelsea. On the 27th of March, at half-past nine o'clock, in consequence of information, I went out and stopped the prisoner going in a direction from my shop—I brought him back, and accused him of stealing a piece of bacon—he took it out of his basket, threw it down, and said, "There it is, do the best you can"—I found a piece of that description missing from my window—this is it—I can swear to it.

Prisoner. Q. How far was I from the shop when you overtook me? A. About 100 yards—you were running—you did not look back—you had apparently had something to drink, but were not so drunk but you knew what you were doing.

WILLIAM CROFTON LEVER (police-constable B 113.) I took the pri
soner into custody, and received this piece of bacon from the prosecutor—the prisoner had a basket with three more pieces of bacon in it—he said at first he had bought them, and afterwards, that he had had them given to him by his old woman.

Prisoner's Defence. I received the bacon from a woman I lived with in Spain, and who robbed me of my money and all—I accidentally met her in a public-house—she had this basket and the bacon in it—she asked if I had any dinner for Sunday—I said no, and she gave me the basket and bacon—she was intoxicated, and afterwards regretted she had given it me, and said, "Let me have it back again"—I said, "No"—she said, "If you don't, I will be revenged on you some way or other"—I said, "Do your best," and went out of the public-house with it, and ran as fast as I could, without the least idea that the bacon was stolen—I believe the very woman that gave me the bacon gave the prosecutor the information.

GEORGE WAISTELL
re-examined. A respectably dressed woman, pass
ing, said, "A man has stolen a piece of bacon from you, and has gone in

that direction"—I could not swear to the woman if I were to see her—she appeared in middling circumstances—the prisoner did not say any thing about any woman at the time, or that the bacon was given to him—from information the police afterwards received) I believe it was a servant in the neighbourhood that gave me the information—he only threw one piece of bacon out of the basket, and that was mine.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined One Month.

1226.
THOMAS HORNER,
JAMES MURPHY,
JOHN COVER , and
JOHN RYDER OWEN , were indicted for
a common assault.

HORNER—
GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

MURPHY, COVER, and OWEN—
GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

1227.
SAMUEL JOHNSON, alias Peter Rogers,
was indicted
for assaulting
William Lenthall Brake and
John Northcole, police constables, in the execution of their duty.

—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1228.
PHILIP LEVY was indicted
for a common assault.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Months.

1229.
BRIDGET TORPEY was indicted
for assaulting
Margaret Hickey.

GUILTY. Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Week,
and to enter into her own recognizances to keep the peace for One Year.

1230.
ALEXANDER BAILEY, alias Marney,
was indicted
for as
saulting
Robert Mason, a constable, in the execution of his duty.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1231.
ISAAC WATFORD, alias John Andrews,
was indicted
for assaulting
Robert Mason, a constable, in the execution of his duty.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1232.
BRYAN FOX was indicted
for assaulting
Charles Marston, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1233.
GEORGE HOWARD was indicted
for assaulting
Richard Etheridge, with intent, &c.

GUILTY .—
Confined Eighteen Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1234.
JAMES RADBURN and
THOMAS DONOVAN were in
dicted for
ripping and stealing 168lbs. weight of lead, value 29s., the goods of
Joseph Fletcher and others, and fixed to a certain building called the
Protestant Dissenters' Original Charity School.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
John Robert Smith; and that Radburn had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN ROBERT SMITH . I am master of the Protestant Dissenters' Original Charity School, in Shakspeare-walk, Shadwell. The back en
trance

is in Collins-court—there is no thoroughfare through that court—I do not know either of the prisoners—on Sunday morning, the 21st of March, I had my attention called to the state of the school-room, and the lead on it—I missed some lead—on the following morning I fitted some lead with the policeman—it had belonged to that roof—I had charge of the premises—Mr. Joseph Fletcher is one of the trustees.

MARY PALMER . I am the wife of Thomas Palmer, and live in Collins-court. I know both the prisoners—Radburn lodged in the same street as I did—my house is on the right-hand side of Collins-court, and on that side there is a vacant piece of ground—about one o'clock in the afternoon of the 20th of March I went into the court to hang up some clothes—I saw Radburn and Donovan both there tossing with money—there were other persons there—at four o'clock in the afternoon I went out again—I went to the top of the court, and saw the prisoners there still—about seven I went out—I did not see the prisoners then—I went to Farmer-street, and returned at half-past seven—I then saw the prisoners by the empty house adjoining the vacant piece of ground—they were talking—there was no one with them—it was about five or six yards from the school-room—the privy is common to all the people of the court—the prisoners went along and round the privy—I then lost sight of them—before they went round there I heard Donovan say to Radburn, "May I go?"—Radburn said to Donovan, "Go, be b—d, who is to hinder you?"—they then went to
wards the privy—I went in-doors, and saw no more.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What are you? A. My husband is a sailor—I am quite sure about the persons I saw in the evening—I did not speak to either of them—I was in the court, outside my window—they went towards the vacant piece of ground—there is a low wall, and part of it does not go quite to the end.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. There is first a short wall, and then a high wall? A. Yes, eight feet high—a person getting on that wall could get to the school-house.

MARY DODD . I am a widow, and live in Collins-court, on the left-hand side. On Saturday, the 20th of March, between eight and nine o'clock at night, I went out for some coals—as I came out I saw the two prisoners going out of the court—I followed them—I had seen them tossing in the court that day—in about five minutes I came back with my coals—the two prisoners were then standing just by the archway—I asked what they wanted there—they answered that they were doing no harm, they would not hurt me—there was a light in Mrs. Sullivan's window—it was shining on them—I am quite sure they are the men—I went out of the court, and watched them—they went out of the court, and turned to the left, and went to a truck standing in Farmer-street, about six doors from the entrance of the court—they leaned on the truck, and then they left, and went towards the public-house, on the other side—I went in-doors—while I was in my room, about nine o'clock, I went to the-window, which is opposite the va
cant piece of ground, and drew my curtain—I saw Mrs. Sullivan, who lives in the court—she had a light in her hand—I saw the prisoners there, close to Mrs. Sullivan—one of them dropped a bag containing something heavy, close to Mrs. Sullivan—they were standing towards the privy—after that one of them struck her by the side of her head—she screamed out, "Murder"—I cannot say which struck her—they ran away up the court—I went out to Mrs. Sullivan—she seemed to have been beaten by

the side of her head—I saw the bag at her feet—a person came and turned it out—it contained lead, which was produced to the policeman—I looked, to see if there was any more lead about, and two pieces were near the privy door—I am positive these are the two men.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see them go into the public-house? A. No—my house is up in the corner, near the school-room—Mrs. Sullivan was standing near the vacant ground—there is a wall between the vacant ground and my house—I was at my window up stairs—the court is two or three yards wide—I go out washing—I gave information directly.

MARY SULLIVAN . I am the wife of Timothy Sullivan, of Collins's-court. On that Saturday night I went out to the privy—I had got a candle in one hand—as I was going in, a tall man in a bluejacket and trowsers came out—he passed me, and momentarily I was knocked down—I called out "Murder"—they did not drop any thing that I observed—when I recovered myself I found at my feet a bag with some lead—I did not see the face of the man, because he held his head on one side—I was not much hurt—I was struck so as to be senseless.
CHARLES BROWN (police-constable K 358.) I went on the Saturday night and took possession of the lead—on the Monday I compared it with the roof of the school-house—in my judgment it came from there.

GEORGE WILLIAM GRAVE (police-sergeant K 11) On Monday morn
ing, the 21st, I took Radburn into custody—I found him in New Gravel-lane—I had known him for some time—I told him I took him for stealing some lead in Collins's-court, Farmer-street—he said, "Farmer-street, I was not there at all after eleven o'clock"—I shortly after apprehended Donovan—I said it was on suspicion of stealing lead in Fanner-street—he said, "I was not down there at all"—I said, "I am given to understand quite different"—he said, "I was there at four in the afternoon."

JAMES READ . I live in Goold-street, St. George's, which is not quite half-a-mile from Collins's-court. I had a truck which I missed at half-past seven o'clock on Sunday morning, the 21st—I saw it safe at six the night before—I had not lent it to any one or permitted any one to take it away—I went to the station a few minutes before nine o'clock on Sunday morning, and there 1 found the truck.

ELIZA SMITH . My father keeps the Royal Sovereign public-house, in Bluegate-fields. On the Saturday evening, before Donovan was taken, he was at our house from six o'clock until twelve at night—my father was out on business in the City—I was serving in the house—Donovan was sitting having his tea about a quarter to seven, along with his father—they were drinking and smoking together there until ten—his father is a coal-whipper—my father did not come home till after twelve—I am sure Donovan was there all that time—he was there till the house shut at twelve—his sister was there about seven—she stopped till ten, and went home with her father.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were the prisoners taken out of your house on the Sunday morning? A. No—some people have been taken there—I do not know how many thieves have been taken out of my father's house, during the last six months—I have not been romping about with the people here—our house was the Blue Gate, but it has since been altered to the Royal Sovereign—no one was at home but me and my brother—one of the men in the tap-room stopped till my father came home—the prisoner went away at twelve o'clock—Radburn was not there, too—

the pot-boy or pot-man is not here—my brother is not here—I do not know where Collins's-court is—Donovan did not stay in the tap-room all the time—only from six to ten, and then he sat at the door—I was sitting at the door part of the time—I am seventeen years old—I have not kept much company with him, I have seen him before—I do not know Radburn—I never saw him until I came here—I was in and out of the tap-room and parlour—I had no one to take any thing in, but me and my brother.

MARY CONLEY . I am sister to Donovan. I know the Royal Sovereign public-house, in Bluegate-fields—I was there the night before my brother was taken—I went at six o'clock in the evening, and staid until ten—my brother was there—my father was sitting with him when I went in—I left my brother there—he was there all the time.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How comes your name to be Conley? A. I am married—I am twenty-two years old—my brother gets his living at coal work—he works with my father—he generally works from five O'clock in the morning until dusk—he had been working with my father the day before at Mrs. Punshon's—my father has got the dropsy and gout—I went out to buy a piece of meat for Sunday's dinner—I live by Shad
well pier.

GEORGE WILLIAM GRAVE
re-examined. I saw Radburn make this statement before the Magistrate—(read)—"I have nothing to say; I must summon witnesses to prove I was in another place."
Radburn. I am guilty of the crime. Donovan is innocent; a man went with me, who is gone to sea.
JAMES M'GILL . I produce the certificate of the prisoner Radburn's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person who was tried.

RADBURN—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

DONOVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1235.
FREDERICK COOLING was indicted
for embezzlement.

GEORGE BENNETT . I am a baker, and live in the Kingsland-road. The prisoner lived with me—it was his duty to take bread to my cus
tomers, and to receive the money from them—he ought to settle his ac
counts every evening—if he received 5l. from Mr. Massey, he has not paid it to me—he did not bring me any account from Mr. Massey—he abscond
ed on that day.
EDWARD MASSEY . I deal with Mr. Bennett—I cannot recognise the prisoner—I paid 5l. on the 4th of September.
ANN DINNIOAN . I am servant to Mr. Massey—the prisoner came for Mr. Bennett's bill—I know him perfectly—he used to bring the bread—I introduced him to my master to be paid.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Do you know what day it was? A. No, I did not see my master pay him—he never came after that day.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1236.
CHARLES MACKEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 violin, value 5s., the goods of
Mary Ann Marriner.

MARY ANN MARRINER . I am a widow, and keep a shop. About six o'clock in the evening, of the 30th of March, the prisoner came into my shop and offered me 1s. for something—I went for change—I then went to the door to another customer—I saw the prisoner moving from the front of the counter to the side, and then he moved back—I saw the end of the

violin under his cloak—he then walked out of the shop, and waited on the step till the child came back with the change—he hand out his hand for the 3d. change, which I was to give him for the waste-paper—I was going to give him the halfpence and said, "Stop, let me see what you have under your cloak," pulling his cloak on one side—he said, "Don't make a fuss about it, what it the value of it?" or words to that effect—I said it was a great shame for a person of his appearance to come and wrong me—this is my violin.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been paralyzed two years, and have not been right in my head, and have been subject to do such things as that.
NOT GUILTY .

1237.
MARY ANN COX was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

ELIZABETH TUCKETT . I conduct the National School in Little Guildford-street, Bloomsbury. About one o'clock on the 10th of March, I was at the school—the prisoner came to me and stated that she met two ladies in the square, and one of them was Miss Powell, who was a teacher in the school—she said that Miss Powell met another lady, who was a teacher in the school, but she did not know her name, and described her dress—that one of these ladies bad bought a bottle-jack of her, and requested it to be brought to me, to be left with me, till she should send her servant to fetch it—she said I was to pay her 5s. for it, and this lady's servant should bring me the money—the bottle-jack was worth 10d. ort 1s.—believing she came from the lady, I gave her the 5s.—I knew Miss Powell very well—I wondered they had not paid for it.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You had some doubt about the truth of her story? A. I cannot say that I doubted, but that remark came into my mind—Little Guildford-street leads out of Great Guildford-street—when she first entered the room, she asked for Miss Tuckett—I said I was Miss Tuckett—she said she had met two ladies in the square, that one was called Miss Powell, that she was a teacher in the school, that she wore a merino dress with two flounces, a scarf, shawl, and a black velvet bonnet, and that was her dress (Miss Powell had been with me not five minutes before,) and that she had met another lady who wore a black shawl and a black silk dress, and that they had purchased the jack of her.

Q. If she had come and used the name of Miss Powell, without describ
ing her dress, should you have let her have the 5s.? A. I very likely should, but the dress confirmed to me that she had evidently seen Miss Powell.

CATHERINE POWELL . I live in Great Coram-street, Brunswick-square. I did not send the prisoner with the bottle-jack—I never saw her till she was before the Magistrate—I did not authorize her to go to Miss Tucket and get two half-crowns.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know this other lady by the description of her dress? A. Yes, Miss Harper, of Henrietta-street—she is a teach in the school with myself—I did not see her that day.
EMMA GAY . I was at the school that day—the prisoner came a bottle-jack, and got 5s.
GEORGE BOTT (police-constable E 26.) I took the prisoner, and have the bottle-jack—it is worth 10d.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1238.
ROBERT STOCK was indicted
for assaulting
Henry Chapman, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1239.
HENRY DEACON was indicted
for assaulting
Frances Dean, with intent, &c.

1240.
WILLIAM GREEN and
SARAH DAVIS were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March, 1 ring, value 8s., the goods of
Joseph Butler.

JOSEPH BUTLER . I live in Newcastle-street, Strand—I go about with a box of jewellery. On the 31st of March I was out, and met Davis and three more women—they asked me what I had got to sell—I said, "I don't think you will buy any thing of me"—I then opened my box—Davis took a ring out, and put it on her finger—she asked me what I wanted for it—I said, 8s. 6d.—there were some more girls who wanted to handle some more goods out of my box, and I would not let them—I shut the box up—I asked Davis to give me that ring back—she would not give it me—she would have run away, but I laid hold of her shawl—she tried to run away, and did run across the court—Green had been looking in my box as well as Davis, and when I took hold of Davis, Green said to me, "If you don't let that woman alone, I will break your nose for you"—I then let Davis go, and she ran away with the ring, and Green ran after her—the policeman came up, and I told him—I have never seen my ring since.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you ever go by the name of Goldfinder? A. No, I have always gone by the name of Joseph Butler—I am a native of Poland—Green did not interfere with me till I took hold of Davis.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Have you been in Newcastle-court? A. Yes—I know two or three women there—I do not know Cowan or Douglas—I never made presents to any of them—I saw Davis again the next morning, in bed—I knew her again—I said to the police
man, "Let her dress herself, I shall know her in a moment."
COURT. Q. Is this the woman that ran away with your ring? A. Yes, I am sure of it—Green was looking into my box at the time she was.
ABRAHAM RANKIN (police-constable F 136.) I took the prisoner—the prosecutor identified the man, but could not exactly identify the woman till she was dressed, he then said she was the woman.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you desire the prosecutor to give a description of the woman who robbed him? A. Yes, he said she was a dark girl with small eyes, that she had a buff gown and a black shawl.

FREDERICK BARTON . I live in Gilbert-street—I was in Newcastle-court, and the prosecutor came, and told me he had lost a ring—there were four or five girls about him—I asked him if it was a fair girl, or a dark one, that took it—he said he did not know, but she had a dark shawl on.
NOT GUILTY .

1241.
JOHN VINCENT was indicted
for assaulting
Henry Gulleford, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 32.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1242.
ROBERT DOWSETT was indicted
for a fraud.
NOT GUILTY .

1243.
JOHN HALEY was indicted
for assaulting
Mary Ann Hendry, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined One Year.

1244.
WILLIAM MILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of March, 8 biscuits, value 2d., and 1 shilling, the property of
Abraham Shott, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 14.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Fourteen Days.

1245.
JAMES BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of April, 1 watch, value 5l.; 2 seals, value 2l.; 1 watch-key, value 10s.; 1 ring, value 9s.; and 1 watch-guard, value 1s.; the goods of
William Vassing
ham.

WILLIAM VASSINGHAM . On the 2nd of April I was at the Two Brewers public-house, at Greenwich, at twenty minutes past ten o'clock at night—the prisoner was there—I was about treating some old pen
sioners—I put my hand into my pocket, and found I was without the means of doing so—I was a little the worse for liquor—I had, no doubt, spent the money—I took the prisoner for the waiter or potman—I gave him my watch, asked him to take it to his master, and ask him to lend me 10s., and I would send for it in the morning—he did not return, and I went to the bar to make inquiry—the landlord and I had a contention about it—I afterwards went out, and met the prisoner in the street—I challenged him with having taken my watch—he denied it on his oath, and words took place between us—a policeman came up—we went back to the house, and my watch was found in his left-band trowsers-pocket.

Prisoner. The gentleman asked me to take his watch, to get some money on it; I did so, and as I was returning to tell him I could not get any thing on it he met me. Witness. My impression is, the prisoner was so drunk he did not know what he was doing; I was not sober; I think he did not mean to steal it.
NOT GUILTY .

1246.
GEORGE WRIGHT and
WILLIAM LAKE were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of March, 1 basket, value 3s. 9d.; 3 planes, value 15s.; 2 saws, value 5s.; I axe, value 3s. 6d.; 3 chisels, value 3s.; 2 mallets, value 1s. 6d.; 1 hammer, value 1s.; 4 gauges, value 1s. 2d.; 1 gimlet, value 3d.; 1 bradawl, value 2d.; and 50 yards of cord, value 3s.; the goods of
Thomas White.

THOMAS WHITE . I am a carpenter, and live in Bridge-street, Green-wich. On the 25th of March I left a basket of tools with Mrs. Wear, the landlady of the Lord Duncan public-house, in the Broadway—I left

them in the cellar—I know the prisoners well—they were coming into the house at the time I got permission to leave them there—I afterwards went with them in to the tap-room, bad some beer, and paid for it—we all three started towards London, and parted near Bermondsey-street—we were going to Mr. Marshall, the agent for emigration—I was to meet the pri
soners again, and waited for them at the turnpike, about half a mile from where I had left my tools—they did not join me, and I went to the Lord Duncan, and found my tools were gone—I did not see either of the pri
soners again till they were in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. I believe you had all three been in the employment of Mr. Clarkson, a builder? A. Yes, for several months—I had been at two public-houses with the prisoners before in the space of twelve months—the last time was about a week before, and a week before that—I think I was drinking with them at the Railway tavern on the 24th of March—Wright pawned his own shovel, as he told me, to pay for beer—he went home to my lodging that night, and staid all night—I did not awake rather thirsty next morning, and want some beer—I did not send Wright to sell a piece of lead for 3d. to get beer—I gave him some lead to get something to eat for himself, not to get beer—we went to the Roebuck public-house—I gave him a stock and bit to pawn that morning, as he said he was very badly off, and had nothing to eat—that was at Deptford, not in the public-house, it was the same day that we went to the Lord Duncan—I was going to Sydney, and they talked about going also—I left them to go to the Victualling-office, and agreed to meet at the turn-pike to go home together—I live at Greenwich, and they at Deptford—I had told them if I could do any thing for them, I would tell them when I met them.

HENRY THURLOW . I am a servant at the Lord Duncan public-house, On the afternoon of the 25th of March the prisoners were there, between three and four o'clock, I was rung for to fetch up the basket of tools from the cellar—I brought them into the tap-room, and delivered them to the prisoners.

JOHN EVANS (police-constable R 190.) On the night of the 25th of March I stopped the prisoners on the Greenwich-road—Lake had a basket—I asked what he had got in it—he said a few tools belonging to his mate—I found it contained two mallets, two chisels, two gauges, one oil-stone, one gimlet, one brad-awl, one hammer, and a file—I asked Wright if the tools belonged to him—he made no reply—I asked him several times—at last he said, "Yes, they are mine, and what more do you want?"—I afterwards showed them to White, who claimed them.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not Wright tell you they belonged to York, and tell you where he lived, and that turned out to be White? A. Yes—the prisoners had been drinking.
NICHOLAS MULLINS . I am a policeman. I took Wright into custody—I was with Evans, and found some duplicates on Wright—five are for the tools which have been pawned.

JOHN LOVICK . I am shopman to Mr. Nash, a pawnbroker, in London-street, Greenwich. I produce two planes, a saw, an axe, and three chisels, pawned on the 25th of March, about a quarter to nine o'clock in the even
ing, by a young man named "George Smith, for Thomas White, No. 2, Bridge-street "—the prosecutor claimed them.
THOMAS CROSSLEY . I am apprentice to Mr. Abithel, a pawnbroker, of

Blackheath-road. I produce a saw and plane pawned on the 25th of March, about seven o'clock in the evening, by Lake, in the name of Tho
mas White, No. 2, Bridge-street.
Cross-examined. Q. White does live in Bridge-street? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

1247.
GEORGE WRIGHT was again indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of March, 1 case of drawing instruments, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas White.

THOMAS WHITE . I lost this case of instruments on Thursday morning out of my house—I allowed Wright to sleep at my house on Sunday night, and while I was gone into the yard they were taken out of the closet in my house.
Prisoner. Q. When you gave me the stock and bit out of the basket, are you sure they were not in the basket? A. They were not.
NICHOLAS MULLINS . I found the duplicate of the instruments on Wright, pawned at Martin's, in Tooley-street.
WILLIAM ADAMS . I produce a case of instruments pawned by Lake for 1s. 6d., who gave his name as White—he was alone.
Prisoner's Defence. When I took them out of the basket, it was all on the same day we were drinking; White had a share of the money in drink.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Weeks.

1248.
ALEXANDER CALVERT and
JOHN BROSNAHAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of March, 1 purse, value 4d.; 2 watch-chains, value 3s.; the goods of
William James Mero: and 8 sovereigns, the monies of
Martin Mero: and
MARY MORIARTY
, for feloniously inciting them to commit the said felony.

WILLIAM JAMES MERO . I am thirteen year old—I am the son of Martin Mero, a manner, and live in Edward-street, Limehouse-fields. On Thursday, the 18th of March, I went to Greenwich—Palmer went with me—I had nine sovereigns, a half-sovereign, and a watch-chain in my pocket—I stole the ten sovereigns from my mother—I left heron the 17th—we went down to the Greenwich rail-road station, and then went to Deptford theatre, after walking about all day—after we came away we came by an eating-house—I said, "I will go and tell a policeman the crime, and he will take me home"—I did not do so—Palmer said, perhaps we might get a lodging-house—we did get one at the prisoner Moriarty's—a man named Smale took us there—Palmer paid her 1s. for the two of us to sleep there that night—she took us to an adjoining house—about nine o'clock next morning she opened the door, and let us out—after walking about all day we came back about a quarter to seven o'clock—after a little while Palmer said he was very dry, and sent Mrs. Moriarty out for a pot of beer, and I sent for a pot, then he sent out for another pot—then Mrs. Moriarty said, "We have had enough beer, let us have some gin"—then Palmer sent out for half a pint of gin, and then there were two half-pints more sent for—by this time we were getting pretty drunk—then she said we had had enough gin, let us have some rum, but she did not return with rum, it was some sickly kind of stuff, it was sweet in your mouth, and bitter afterwards—I know the taste of rum—she returned with it in a pint pot, and told Palmer to drink hearty out of it—he did so, and

returned it to her—then she poured me out a glassful, and told me to drink that—Palmer jumped about a little while, and fell fast asleep, and was sick—then she said it was almost time to go to bed—I was rather sleepy—she put us to bed—I was so drunk I could not put myself to bed—Calvert carried Palmer up to bed—Calvert was only there when the gin and rum were sent for—there were three men and three girls there when the gin was being sent for, and some part of the beer, and so were Brosnahan and Smale—I was sober enough to see and know them—Bros
nahan, Smale, and Calvert were there when we had the gin—Calvert carried Palmer into bed, and I walked in—Brosnahan and Smale went in with us—I do not know where Mrs. Moriarty was when we went to bed—I put the money between the two sheets—it was in a little leather purse—I do not think any body saw me do it—I went to sleep—we. went to bed between one and two o'clock—I awoke before daylight, felt for my money, but found it was gone—I fell off to sleep again—Mrs. Moriarty afterwards opened the door—I told her immediately she came in, and she said, "Oh non
sense, come and have some breakfast," and I went and had some breakfast with her—she never asked me for the money to pay for it—I have never seen the bag or money since.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You stood all this drinking very well, you were quite able to see and know what you were about, when you got into bed? A. Not quite—I had my senses a little—my mother works as a tailoress—I dare say this was some little money she had saved up—I took it from underneath her bed, from between the two beds.

COURT. Q. What did Mrs. Moriarty say to you? A. When she was washing Palmer's trowsers, she called me back, and told me if any body asked me if I was robbed, I was to say no—I did not make any answer, but walked away—the witness Potter told me to go and call a policeman—I walked out, but could not see one—I came back again, and sat there all day, till six o'clock, till Bovis the policeman came, and told me to go to the station.

RICHARD SMITH LAWRENCE PALMER . I went with Mero to Greenwich that day—we went to the Deptford Theatre, then went to Mrs. Moriarty's, and had spirits, beer and rum—Mero and I had a watch-chain a piece—we gave 3s. 10d. for the two, which we paid for out of the money Mero took from his mother—I saw Mero with ten sovereigns—he had got them in some paper when I first saw them—we bought two purses each—after having the rum we went to bed—they carried me into bed—I was drunk and sick—I do not know what became of Mero—I cannot say at what time I awoke in the morning—it was light—Mero said he had lost his mo
ney—we went to Mrs. Moriarty—she told him not to mind, it was non
sense—I have never seen the chains or money since.

HARRIET POTTER . I am single, and lodge at Mrs. Moriarty's—it is a house of ill-fame—I remember Calvert, Brosnahan, and the two boys being there on the evening in question, and the beer being brought in—I and Shore went up stairs with the boys—they were taken in the adjoin
ing house by Mrs. Moriarty, and while she was gone to take the two chil
dren, I and Shore went up stairs to bed—I saw Moriarty go out of one house into the other—there is a communication between the two houses—Mero asked me if my name was not Eliza Payter, as I was very much like a person he knew of that name—I said I was not—he was not very drunk—I saw a sovereign in his hand—he asked me if I thought it would be

safe if he placed it in Moriarty's hands—I said I was rather a stranger there myself, and would rather not have any thing to say in it—Brosnahan came up into the room where I was, and laid on the bed with his clothes on for about five minutes—Calvert came to the foot of the stairs, and I heard him say, "It is all right"—Brosnahan then went down.
Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you are an unfortunate young woman? A. I am sorry to say I am—I have been so a month.

SARAH SHORE . I am nineteen years old—I lodge at Mrs. Moriarty's. I recollect Mero and Palmer coming—I asked Moriarty whether she had such little children as them lodging in her house—she said yes, she would rather trust them than me—Palmer was dancing with Moriarty, and after that the boys wanted to go to bed—Moriarty took a light and showed them into the next house—I slept with Potter—Smale and Bros
nahan afterwards came into our room—Calvert came to the foot of the stairs and called them down—on the Thursday night I heard Calvert say he bad no money, and ask Mrs. Moriarty to trust him.

ARTHUR SAUNDERS . I am bar-boy at the Cricketers' public-house, in King-street, Greenwich. On Saturday morning, the 20th of March, about half-past five o'clock, Calvert and two others, who I do not know, came into the tap-room, and had some ginger-beer and ale—they gave some money to an old collegeman, who was waiting on them—I do not know what money they gave him—it was silver or copper, not gold—about half-past eight or nine, Calvert came in by himself, and had a bottle of ginger-beer—he threw down a sovereign—I was rather surprised, and asked him if he bad any more of that sort—he said he had had one—our potman, who was standing by, asked him to stand something—he said he might have what be liked, and he had a bottle of ginger-beer—I observed that he had a red-scarf on his neck, which I understood him to say he had just bought for 3s. 6d.

GEORGE BEAVER . I am a shoemaker, and live in Greenwich Market. On Saturday, the 20th of March, about seven o'clock, Calvert and Bros
nahan came to my shop and had a pair of shoes each, for which Calvert paid me a sovereign.

HENRY JULIE . I am shopman to Mr. Cadwell, a linen-draper, in Greenwich. On Saturday, the 20th of March, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning, Calvert bought a scarlet handkerchief of me, for which he paid two half-crowns.

JOHN DOWSON . On Saturday morning, about nine or ten o'clock, Cal
vert came with others and redeemed a coat and handkerchief, which came to 8s. 3d.—he gave me a sovereign.

WILLIAM HOLMES . I keep the King's Arms, Greenwich. On Satur
day morning, the 20th of March, about a quarter-past seven o'clock, Cal
vert and Brosnahan came to my house and had some beef-steaks—Calvert changed two sovereigns and Brosnahan one—Culvert showed a scarf to Brosnahan, and said he had bought it for a crown—I saw more gold in Brosnahan's hand when he changed the sovereign.

JAMES OAKE . I am a hatter at Greenwich. On Saturday, the 20th, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, Calvert came and introduced Brosnahan as a gentleman that wanted a hat—Brosnahan paid me a crown, two half-crowns, and a shilling—Calvert had a hat at the same time, for which he paid two half-crowns, and I saw some gold in his hand at the time.

HENRY YOUENS . I live at Greenwich. On Friday night, the 19th of March, about eleven o'clock, I saw Calvert—he asked me for 1d. to get half a pint of beer—I gave it him, and he went over to the White Hart public-house and had it.
Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. Conductor to an omnibus— I know Calvert by working about the flys and vans—he has worked for Mr. Stacey, a fly-master.

EDMUND BURKE . About half-past eleven o'clock on this Friday night, I was standing at the White Hart public-house—Calvert came over from the Mitre, and asked me for a halfpenny for a pipe of tobacco—I gave it him.

JOHN BOVIS (police-constable R 139.) In consequence of information, I went to Moriarty and asked her who the parties were that were drinking there that night—she pointed to a young man and woman sitting there, and said there were two other young women that were there, but were not at home then—I asked her if she was sure there was no one else—she said, "Yes"—I asked her was not Jack and Alic there—(meaning Smale and Calvert)—she said, "Yes, they were all there"—I asked her who fetched the drink for the boys—she said she did—I asked her when the boys com
plained to her in the morning, whether she went out to tell a policeman—she said, no, she did not—I then asked Brosnahan who put the boys to bed—(Brosnahan was present)—he said, nobody, his mother took a light as far as the door.

JOHN SIZER (police-constable R 103.) I took Calvert on Monday the 22nd—I found on him a new hat, and a new pair of shoes—I know Bros
nahan to be an associate of Calvert's, they frequent Moriarty's house—I have seen them about the neighbourhood, and I saw them the morning after the robbery, drinking at the Mitre public-house, where I was—he is Moriarty's son, or passes as her son.
Brosnahan. Q. Where have you seen me associate with this man? A. I have seen you in company with him by Skelton's-lane, and likewise in front of the church—I have frequently seen them pass together.
CHARLOTTE MERO . I am the wife of Martin Mero, and live in Edward-street, Limehouse-fields. I lost ten sovereigns on Wednesday night, the 17th of March.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Palmer? A. He is a neighbour's child.
JAMES HARGRAVE , I apprehended Palmer—he told me he had been robbed at Greenwich, and I took him to the office—I had bills printed to apprehend the boys.
Cross-examined. Q. What were the bills about? A. The two boys having left their home; Palmer told me of this instantly I took him.

WILLIAM JAMES MERO
re-examined. Moriarty went for every thing we had to drink, except half a pint of beer, and half a pint of gin; I and another young man went for that—I do not know when it was that Cal
vert and Brosnahan came in—Moriarty had been out—they came in soon after she had been out—they spoke very friendly, as if they were ac
quainted—after we had been drinking a little while, Calvert said, "I will take you in an omnibus, and we will ride all round Lewisham "—I did not see Moriarty in the room when we went to bed, but Brosnahan, Cal
vert, and Smale were there.
Brosnahan's Defence. I came home in my vessel on Friday evening—

these two boys were sitting by the fire—I bad my supper, and each of the boys had a part of it—they asked my mother whether she would trust them with a night's lodging, and said they were going to Woolwich in the morning to their friends, and would get money to pay her, and they had no money till then—in the morning I and this young man went out to
gether, and had a pint or two of beer together—I said I was going to buy a pair of shoes, and he said he was going to do the same.
Moriarty's Defence. I don't know any thing about the money; the boy brought in a glass of beer, and gave it to the other.

CALVERT—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

BROSNAHAN—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

MORIARTY†—
GUILTY . Aged 62.
Transported for Seven Years.

1249.
JOHN GREEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of March, 43lbs. weight of iron, value 4s. 6d., the goods of the
London and Birming
ham Railway Company, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1250.
BRIDGET MARY BLAKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of March, 1 crown, and 2 half-crowns, the moneys of
George Luff, from his person.

GEORGE LUFF . I am a pewterer. On the 31st of March I met the prisoner in Church-street, Greenwich, between six and seven o'clock—we spoke, and went to a public-house, and then to a brothel—I gave her a shilling—I was there about a quarter of an hour—I was on the bed with her—I had a crown and two half-crowns in my right-hand pocket, and when I got up I missed my money out of my trowsers' pocket—I had not taken my trowsers off—I charged the prisoner with it—she denied having any money—I went to the window, and called the police.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was that the first night you had known the prisoner? A. I had been in her company previously—I did not know she was married—I had seen her at the Bricklayers' Arms pub
lic-house—we bad a pint of ale that night, we then went to the Dover Castle—we had no rum—the prisoner denied having any of my money.

MARY WALKER . I am the wife of a policeman. The prisoner was brought to the station; I searched her, I found a crown-piece under her arm, and she dropped a half-crown on the floor—I do not know where the half-crown came from.
NOT GUILTY .

1251.
GEORGE JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 1 pair of shoes, value 2s., the goods of
James Gillham; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1252.
CLARISSA PREBBLE was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1253.
WILLIAM DAVIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 1 pair of trowsers, value 2s.; 1 pair of boots, value 3s.; and 1 hand
kerchief, value 4d.; the goods of
Robert Wilkie: 1 jacket, value 8s.; and 1 flannel shirt, value 1s.; the goods of
Nicholas Mainger: in a vessel on the navigable river Thames: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

1254.
THOMAS CAMPBELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, at St. Mary, Newington, 1 basin, value 1d.; 3 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 1 crown, 14 half-crowns, 26 shillings, 3 sixpences, and 3 groats; the property of
George Berry, in his dwelling-house; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1255.
JOHN DAWSEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 1 rule, value 5s.; 6 half-crowns, and 5 shillings; the property of
Samuel Barnsley, from his person.

SAMUEL BARNSLEY . I am a carpenter, and live in Beer-lane, Christ-church, Surrey. I was at the King of Prussia public-house on Saturday night, the 3rd of April, at a little after twelve o'clock—I was a little the worse for liquor, but not much—I had six half-crowns, five shillings, and a rule—when I got out I sat down on a step—I could have walked hone if I had been let alone—several people came round me—three people said they knew me, and lifted me up, and one of them took me on his back—when I came a little to my senses I found my shoulder hurt very much, and missed my money and rule—I was thrown down by the party, which made me insensible for an hour—I was not very drunk.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why not get off the man's back if you were so sober? A. I was never carried before—they took hold of my arm to lift me up—nobody took hold of my legs—I told them to let me alone, but they would take me—I knew when I was on the man's back—they would not let me get down—I had about three pints of beer and one glass of gin—I was carried sixty or a hundred yards.

MARIA JONES . I live with my mother and father, in Red Lion-court, Union-street. I was in Gravel-lane on the 3rd of April—as I passed the King of Prussia public-house they turned the prosecutor out, and he sat on the step of a door—he appeared drunk—a mob got round him—he was lifted on a man's back, and carried to the Two Brewers public-house—as they went along I saw the prisoner walk by the side of the man who carried him, and when they got him down to the Two-Brewers they flung him down, and he fell on his shoulder—I saw the prisoner feel in his waistcoat pocket—he did not appear to take any thing out of it, but then he felt in his trowsers pocket, and took something out—I did not see a rule—I had known the prisoner for above twelve months—there were only three about the prosecutor at the time—after that the prisoner went with the other two men to a pork-shop in Gravel-lane—they stood at a window there, and he shared the money between the three—I saw money pass from him to the two—they left the prosecutor lying on the ground, not very far from the pork-shop.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not he able to get up? A. No—he appeared drunk—I think it was all shillings that I saw pass between them—I was going for some beer for my mother's supper when I saw this—my mother came home late, poorly, or I should have been in bed—I mentioned this when I came home—the mob went away—my mother told me the man's name when I described him to her—she said she knew him—I knew him before, but not his name—I told her he bad a blue jacket and canvass trowsers, and then she knew his name by the description I gave her.
COURT. Q. Did you give any further description of him? A. No—ray mother raid his name was John Dawsey—I told her nothing else, but that I had seen him before in Union-street.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where was your mother that night? A. At home—she gave information that I knew who the man was.

RICHARD WHBATLEY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody, from the prosecutor, on Monday the 5th, at the Three Sugar Loaves public-house, Union-street—the prosecutor looked in at the door at the time I brought him out—he said he knew nothing about it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you search him? A. Yes, and found 1s. 8d. on him, and a duplicate of a hat.
NOT GUILTY .

1256.
CHARLES KNIGHT and
JOHN TAYLOR were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of March, 1 gelding, price 6l., the property of
William Prior.

WILLIAM PRIOR . I live at Battersea. On the 4th of March I had a gelding safe—on the 5th I sent for it, and it was gone—I had turned him out in Battersea Marsh—I found it on the 8th, at Mr. Towell's stables—I know nothing of either of the prisoners.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What sort of place is the Marsh? A. About three hundred acres of land, which is inclosed all round with a large ditch, five or six feet wide, and the stream of a sewer runs round it—I do not know whether the gelding could jump.
COURT. Q. It was of very small value? A. About 6l.—it cost 6l. 5s.—my brother had turned him out.

ISAAC PRIOR . I am the prosecutor's brother. I turned the horse out on the Marsh, on the 4th of March—I missed him on the 5th, and saw him again on the 8th, at Towell's stables in Clerkenwell—I do not know either of the prisoners.
HENRY HUSSEY . I lost a horse myself, which was fed with Prior's, my neighbour—I found them both at Towell's on the 7th of March—I never saw the prisoners till they were in custody.

HENRY TOWELL . I am a horse-slaughterer. Prior's horse was found in my possession, on the 7th of March—it was brought to me by the pri
soner Knight, on the 5th of March, about eight o'clock in the morning—there was another horse with it—he offered them both to me—I bought the two for 50s.—he said he had brought them from Mr. Renton's, soap-maker, Park-place, Walworth, and he must see them slaughtered—I told him to bring them down to my premises—this was on Clerkenwell-green—I told him I could not slaughter them then, for my inspector did not come before ten o'clock—I do not slaughter any horses till the inspector has seen them—he brought the horses down to my place, No. 1, Bowling-street, Clerkenwell—I paid him for them—he said he would come in an hour and see them slaughtered—he did not come, and I had suspicion,

and sent over to Mr. Renton to know if he had sent them—I never saw the prisoner again till he was taken, which was three weeks afterwards—Taylor had hold of the horses' heads on Clerkenwell-green—my dealings were with Knight—Prior came and claimed one of the horses on the 8th—Hussey saw them on the 7th—I delivered them to them.
WILLIAM READ . I am a policeman. I apprehended Knight in James-street, Walworth, on the 27th of March—I told him I took him for horse-stealing—he said nothing.

WILLIAM LEE . I apprehended the prisoner Taylor at No. 12, James-street, Was worth, on the 27th of March, at the same time as Knight—they were apprehended together—I found a pair of scissors in the house, which I produce.
EDWARD HUSSEY . I saw Prior's horse at Towell's, and know it to he his—I saw my father's horse there also.

Cross-examined. Q. You were living with your father at the time you turned the horse out? A. Yes—that was not Prior's horse—I know his horse—I have been in prison once, at Brixton, after I had been tried—it was three or four years ago—it was not for horse-stealing—I was in cus
tody for horse-stealing six or seven years ago—I do not know how this horse got away—I am certain of that.
Q. Was it you first discovered the loss? A. My father went out first, and I went out after him—we went found together.

HENRY HUSSEY
re-examined. I know the horse which Towell gave up to be Prior's.

ISAAC PRIOR
re-examined. I am quite sure the horse found at Towell's, is my brother's, which I had turned out.

KNIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

TAYLOR—
NOT GUILTY .

1257.
CHARLES KNIGHT and
JOHN TAYLOR were again in
dicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March, 1 mare, price 4l. 10s., the pro
perty of
William Paul Mellish.

WILLIAM PAUL MELLISH . I live at Wands-worth. On the 24th of March I had a brown mare with three white feet, a white face, and a long tail—I turned her out on Wands worth-common, and fettered her feet to prevent her straying—next morning, at six o'clock, she was gone—I gave infor
mation at the station, and on the Friday the prisoner Knight was brought to me in custody, in Smithfield—I went with him to White's slaughter-house in Whitechapel, and found my mare there—the prisoner was allowed to go away—the mare had her tail cut, and her heels trimmed when I found her—she had cost me 4l. 10s. four months before.

HANNAH SMITH . I live at No. 18, James-street, Walworth. The pri
soner Knight took a house of me on the 20th of March—he was alone—I saw him in the house on the 25th of March, and Taylor was riding a horse up and down the street—he went to the house where Knight was, got off the horse, led it through into the yard, and tied it up—it had a white face—next morning I saw Taylor in the yard, trimming the horse—Knight was present.
BENJAMIN WHITE . I live in Thomas-street, Whitechapel. On Friday

morning Knight brought me the mare in question, and wanted a sovereign for it—he said he came from White-square, Clapham—I asked who re
commended him to me—he said, a gentleman in Berraondsey-street—I asked where he lived himself—he said, in White-square, Clapham—I offered him 15s. for her—he went outside with her, came back, and said he would take 16s. for her, which I gave him—in consequence of information, I went out afterwards to look after Knight—I found him with Taylor, at Aldgate—they were walking together—I brought him back to my shed.
WILLIAM READ . I apprehended the prisoners together.

KNIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

TAYLOR—
NOT GUILTY .

1258.
JOHN TAYLOR was again indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of March, 1 mare, price 4l., the property of
Henry Hussey: upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

1259.
JOHN SINCLAIR was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of March, 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 flannel-shirt, value 1s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s. 6d.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 3s.; 2 shirts, value 3s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 14s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 4s.; and 1 pair of braces, value 1d.; the goods of
William Emmer
son:
1 coat, value 10s.; 1 jacket, value 7s. 6d.; and 1 box of do
minoes, value 2d.; the goods of
Richard Parkinson:
1 cap, value 1s., the goods of
Charles Crew:
1 bag, value 1d., the goods of
Richard Skipper, from a vessel on the navigable river Thames; to all of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1260.
JAMES WILLIAM ALLSHORN was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of December, 27 1/2 yards of printed cotton, value 20s.; and 1 looking-glass and stand, value 20s., the goods of
Frederick Piggott his master; and
JAMES EDWARD ALLSHORN
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

FREDERICK PIGGOTT . I am an upholsterer, and live in George-street, Richmond. James William Allshorne was living with me as clerk—he came to me in August—on Saturday, the 18th of March, the policeman came and told me he had found some duplicates on my clerk's father, and amongst them one for some printed cotton, and another for some furniture and a looking-glass—he showed me the one for the cotton, which was at a pawnbroker's at Richmond—I went there and identified it—the glass produced is mine, and this is my cotton—one parcel of it was pawned at Richmond; and this is the other part of it—I missed them when I came to examine my stock—James William Allshorn was then living with me—I did not know that he had a father till a few weeks before that.

James William Allshorn. Q. How do you know that to be your cot
ton? A. By this mark at the back of it, which corresponds with the other piece—I bought two pieces on the 13th of November, and here is the corresponding piece, which has the same mark—I know the glass by a private mark on the back of it, which has been partly erased, but not suf
ficiently—I believe it is your writing.
WILLIAM WYLLIE . I am assistant to Mr. Edwards, a pawnbroker. This seven yards and a half of cotton were pawned by James Edward Allshorn, the father, on the 23rd of December, in the name of Jones.
PHILIP ROSE . I am assistant to a pawnbroker in Holborn. I produce a swing-glass and some cotton, pawned with me, on the 24th of December, by Henry Allshorn.

STEPHEN CREED (police-constable V 200.) I went to search the resi
dence of James Edward Allshorn—I saw him throw a paper parcel out of his pocket behind the door—I picked it up, and it contained seven dupli
cates; and, on searching him, I found the duplicate of the seven yards and a half of cotton pawned at Richmond.

WILLIAM IRELAND (City police-constable, No. 130.) I found the du
plicate of the other cotton and the glass on Henry Allshorn.

FREDERICK PIGGOTT
re-examined. When James William Allshorn was locked up, I asked him if there was any thing else he had taken—he said, "Yes, there is the glass, and the other furniture, that is all"—he was going on to state about some money he had kept from me, when the po
liceman came up, and advised him to say no more.

John William Allshorn. He came and held out an inducement to me that he would be as lenient as possible, and he gave me two hours to con
sider of it. Witness. No, I told him if I found more property, it might make me more severe—I said, "You had better tell me where it is, it may save me trouble"—he had told me of the glass before, and said he did not pledge it himself.

James Edward Allshorn's Defence. On the 23rd of December I was in London; my son Henry told me be could make me a present of some cotton, to cover some chairs that I had, and I accepted it, not questioning but that he had purchased it, and the glass too, as he said he had.
HENRY ALLSHORN (a prisoner.) I did make my father a present of it.

JAMES WILLIAM ALLSHORN—
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined One Year.

JAMES EDWARD ALLSHORN—
NOT GUILTY .

1261.
JOHN MILLER was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

SUSAN MUCKLOW . I am a widow, and a baker; I live in High-street, Peckham. In the evening of the 12th of March, the prisoner came and asked for a pennyworth of biscuits—he gave me a sixpence—I said it was bad—he said he did not know it—he gave me another—I saw that was bad—I bent them both—he left the biscuits, and went out—I sent my lad after him—in ten minutes he was brought back by a constable—I kept the six
pences in my hand, and marked them, and gave them to the officer—I said to the prisoner, at first, "If I had a policeman here, I would give you into custody"—I kept both the sixpences in my hand till the constable brought him back.

CHARLES WHITE (police-constable P 57.) On Friday evening, the 12th of March, between seven and eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner in High-street, Peckham, about three yards from Mrs. Mucklow's shop—I did not see him go into her shop, but a lad came out and told me something—I

ing to a gentleman's house, which was no thoroughfare—I followed, and found him standing with his back against a tree—I then took hold of him—he said he had done nothing—I took him back to Mrs. Mucklow's shop, searched him, and found on him one good half-crown, one good sixpence, and 1s. 2d. in copper, all good.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. These sixpences are both counterfeit, and both cast in one mould; the other money is all good.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to Greenwich to look for work; I had change for a half-sovereign at a house where I stopped for the evening; I cannot give any account of these sixpences, only I took them at the house where I changed the half-sovereign; I should not have offered them if I had known it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Six Months.

1262.
JAMES PERRIN was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1263.
THOMAS DODD was indicted
for feloniously receiving of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 9th of March, 1 brush, value 1s.; the goods of
William Metcher; well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
WILLIAM METCHER . I am a bricklayer, living in Ann-street, Waterloo-road. I lent a brush of mine to Garland—this now produced is it—I know it by the irregularity of the hairs, and the handle.

JOHN GARLENT . I had this brush from the prosecutor—I took it to Norwood, where I was plastering—on Monday, the 8th of March, it was missing—I had left it safe on Saturday evening, the 6th, in the fire-place—the house was locked—the jamb was broken from the door
way.

WILLIAM COCKRILL (police-constable L 108.) I went to search the pri
soner's premises on the 24th of March—I found this duplicate there, which led me to the pawnbroker's, where I found this brush—there were thirty-five duplicates belonging to the prisoner.

Prisoner. I purchased it of a person that came to my shop, where I sell carpenters' tools, and other things; I asked what he wanted for it, and he said, 1s.; I gave it him; and, wanting some money, I pawned it at Mr. Beck's, in Blackfriars'-road, for 6d. Witness. His uncle died a short time ago, and left him some tools, and he opened a little shop—I found this book there, in which there was nothing entered on the 9th of March, when this was pawned—I believe he has no license as a marine-store dealer.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1264.
WILLIAM KILLICK and
JOHN HART were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April, 241bs. weight of soap, value 10s., the goods of
Benjamin Hawes and others, their masters.
JAMES BROOK (Police-constable L 118.) On the 2nd of Apnl, in the

evening, I was at Lambeth—I was not on duty, nor in my uniform—I saw the two prisoners, about a quarter-past eight o'clock, in Stamford-street—Hart was carrying a bundle containing soap in a Macintosh cape—they crossed into the York-road, and went down Button-street, and when they got to the bottom of that I saw Hart give Killick the bundle—I then stopped Killick, and asked what he had—he said, "Some soap"—I asked him where he got it from—he said he found it—Hart then ran away, Goff, who was with me, ran after him and brought him back—Killick owned the Macintosh, and I found in it six bars of mottled soap—I searched Killick, and found in his pockets four half-bars of soap—I found some receipts on him—I found where Hart lived, and went to the house in company with Goff—the prisoners were not going towards his house when I saw them.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. This was on Friday evening? A. Yes—the prisoners were in Stamford-street when I first saw them.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 31.) On Friday night I was in the York-road, and saw the two prisoners walking together—I saw Hart run away, and I went in pursuit of him—I ran twenty or thirty yards, and secured him—I found nothing on him—I asked him where be brought the soap from—he said, "From home"—I asked where he lived—he said, close by, and he was going to take the soap to that man's (point
ing to Killick)—I afterwards went to the address that Hart gave, at No. 5, Angel-place—he and his mother have one room there—I found two pieces of soap in the cupboard.

JOHN MEAGER . I am clerk to Benjamin, Thomas, and William Hawes. The prisoners were employed by them as carmen, and when they were not employed in delivering soap, they were engaged on the premises—they leave at seven o'clock in the evening—Killick was carrying out mottled soap on the 1st of April, and on the 2nd they had both been carrying out yellow soap—this mottled soap is my employers', and this yellow also—there is a little imperfection in the machine which cuts it, and one side is thicker than the other—that is the case with these outside bars—Hart was employed occasionally in the warehouse as a packer—here is about 28lbs. of soap, worth about 13s.

Cross-examined. Q. About how much soap in the course of a year is cut by this machine, which is imperfect? A. Several hundred tons—this machine is always used, and all the soap sold by us has the same mark—the mottled soap sent out by Killick on the Thursday had the same imper
fection—he had two small parcels to deliver that day, one at Lambeth and one at the London Hospital—about 1 3/4 cwt. in all—neither of these cus
tomers are here to-day—we have had Hart for several years—I believe his father was there for thirty years—the gate-keeper is there till eight o'clock in the evening.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is there any other circumstance except the out
side bars that you can speak to? A. The mottled soap was not a good boiling—the mottle did not come out well, and the mottle in this soap is not out so well as we could wish—there was soap of this boiling in the warehouse.
WILLIAM WATSON . I am groom to one of the Messrs. Hawes. I know this Macintosh—I have seen Killick wear it—he told me he made it himself.

JOHN LYNCH . I am gate-keeper at Messrs. Hawes. The two pri
then followed the prisoner—he crossed the road, and went up a walk lead-soners
left their premises, on the 2nd of April, between half-past seven and eight, o'clock.

KILLICK—
GUILTY . Aged 31.

HART—
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months.

1265.
AUGUSTA LAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of March, 1 spoon, value 4s. 6d.; part of a brooch, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Ed
ward Dutton, her master.

EDWARD DUTTON . The prisoner was my servant—she came to me on the 2nd of March—I saw this spoon safe on the 28th of February, the day before she came—I missed it on the last day of February, or the 1st of March—I supposed the other girl had lost it—I saw nothing of the spoon till the 15th of March, when the policeman brought it—this brooch is also mine—it was safe seven or eight days before—it was found on her—I swear it is my property.
ELIZABETH DUCKETT . I am the wife of Joseph Ducket, a policeman. I searched the prisoner one Monday—I do not know when—I found 9s. 6d. on her, and the brooch in her bosom.
JAMES UPJOHN . The prisoner came to my shop on the 15th of March, about three o'clock in the afternoon—she offered this spoon for sale—I detained it and her.
CHARLES JACKS (police-sergeant T 20.) I took the prisoner in charge.
NOT GUILTY .

1266.
AUGUSTA LAY was again indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of March, 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 5 pieces of silk, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 1 printed-book, value 1s. 6d.; 1 fork, value 6d.; 1 brooch, value 6d.; the goods of
John George, her master.

JOHN GEORGE . I live at Richmond. The prisoner was in my service for about seven weeks—she left me on the 1st of March—on the 15th I was told something, and missed the things stated—these now produced are mine.
CHARLES JACKS (police-sergeant F 20.) I searched the prisoner's box, and found these articles in it.
GUILTY. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined Nine Days.

1267.
ROBERT LOOSELY was indicted
for receiving, on the 31st of March, 21bs. weight of marjoram seed, value 14s., the goods of
James Richard Tyler, well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JAMES RICHARD TYLER . I am a seeds-man, living at New Brixton. I bought 3lbs. of marjoram seed at Mr. Sangston's—I sold 1lb. of it, and lost the other from the seed room—it was in a paper bag—I believe this now produced to be mine.
ALEXANDER ANDERSON LANGSTON . Here is my writing on this bag, the same as there was on the bag I sold to Mr. Tyler, and the name of its seed "knotted marjoram."

EDWARD DENVER . I am a seedsman at Brixton. On the 31st of March, the prisoner came with this seed to sell—I asked him what he wanted for it—he said 4s. or 5s. a pound—I had known him as being in the habit of buying seed of me and others—I have always considered him very honest—I had the best opinion, of him—I told him the quantity was of no use to me.
Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How long have you known him? A. Four or five years—he was an honest, hard working man.

WILLIAM WOODWARD (police-constable P 157.) I was sent for and took the prisoner—this is the seed—the prisoner said his wife received it from a person he did not know, and his wife told me she received it from a person who has absconded.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 10TH, 1841.
